div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.

div.head: Egyptian Cotton at Manchesters Docks
div.p: The visit to the Manchester Docks of a large party of Lancashire cotton spinners yesterday week must have been a revelation to many of the enormous extent and admirable character of the accommodation now afforded by the Port of Manchester for direct cotton imports. The visitors were also ableto see for themselves the careful, expeditious, and thoroughly business like way in which cotton is handled by the Ship Canal Company's men. But perhaps the most striking sight says the “Manchester Guardian" was the contrast afforded between the condition in which American and Egyptian bales arrive in this country. Beside the same quay the steamers “Eastry,” from Savannah, and “Merchant Prince,” from Alexandria, were both discharging cotton cargoes. Out of the hold of the ‘Eastry’ came a constant succession of what can only by courtesy be described as bales at all they looked more like dilapida ted ragbags, in spite of the most careful banding they shed part of their precious contents at every movement, and it was perfectly obvious that never at any time had the majority of them been even decently covered. Out of the “Merchant Prince” came the Egyptian bales, perfectly rectangular, neat, and trim, clearly marked, and with hardly a lock ot cotton visible anywhere. The American bales may have suffered severer treatment on the other side before shipment—doubtless they had,—-but that is reason why they should be better, not worse, packed. The truth is that the wrappers on American bales have almost ceased to be a scandal and have become a mere derision. They are no longer wrappers, but a technical pretence —vestiges, still discernible but becoming fainter and fainter, of an ancient custom, long ago abandoned, of protecting American cotton from wet, dirt, and loss in transit; aud we imagine that the most substantial realities remaining in connection with them are the charges made for the work which is no longer done and for the material which is no longer used. How long, we wonder, will English and Continental spinners consent to . tolerate this impudent fiction.

div.p: The Turkish transport S.S. “Al Shark” is on its way to Hodeida from Smyrna with 550 troops

div.head: The Mecca Pilgrimage
div.p: The Algerian Sheikh el Senoussi accompanied by 1,000 Algerian pilgrims have left Suez for Mecca

div.head: Troopships
div.p: The trropship "Dongola" left Suez on Sunday afternoon bound for Karachi. The "Assaye", which is homeword bound, is due at Suez on the 16th

div.head: The Greek Census
div.p: It is estimated that the Greek colony of Egypt is about 200,000, of which 24,000 are resdident in Cairo and a minimum of 30,000 in Alexandria

div.head: Cairo-Alexandria Trains
div.p: The normal working of the trains was resumed yesterday evening over the Tewfikieh bridge at Benha and the service of trains between Cairo and Alexandria is now proceeding without interruption.

div.head: Ottoman Railway Lottery
div.p: The Imperial Ottoman Bank at Alexandria has received a cable from Constantinople to the effect that the “gros lot” in the Ottoman Railway lottery ofthe 30th November has been drawn by the number 1,656,944

div.head: Theft of Bank Notes
div.p: The day betore yesterday a judge of the Native Courts, living at Ramleh, was the victim of a thieft who has successfully, up to the present, absconded with bank notes to the value of L.E. 660, which were extracted from a drawer of his desk. The efforts of the police to obtain a clue have so far been absolutely fruit.

div.head: Esneh Barrage
div.p: A rumour has been current to the effect that the Irrigation Department are suspending all work in the way of erecting new pumps, etc, until the completion of the Esneh Barrage This is entirely without foundation, as any works of this nature which bave been contemplated will be carried out in the ordinary way, the barrage affecting them in no way

div.head: Cairo to Luxor
div.p: Last night the orginary winter service of the trains de luxe between, Cairo and Alexandria was commenced, and there will therefore be no sleeping cars attached to the 8. p.m. train. The trains de luxe will leave Cairo at 6 p.m. on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Satardays, and Laxor at the same hour on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays

div.head: Return of the COngo Pigmies
div.p: The pigmies from the Ituri Forest who were brought over to England by Colonel Harrison have left on their return to the Congo Forest. Colonel Harrison will join them at Port Said, whence the party will travel via Mombasa, Uganda, and Toro to the Ituri. The pigmies are in hoodhealth Col. Harrison, after seeing his charges safely home, hopes to return to England next May

div.head: Greek Steamer Wrecked
div.p: The Hellenic steamer “Anonymos” has been wrecked on its way to Alexandria from Cyprus, carring a cargo of caribs. The steamer was caught in a storm near the coast of Cyprus and lost her rudder. Her engines also broke down and she was thrown on the rocks Her crew of 25 escaped ina boat, and one man had both legs broken. The "Anonymos" was of 1500 tons end was insured with the Adriatica.

div.head: Hedjaz Railway
div.p: The S.S. “Cossovo" of the Mahsusseh Company is shortly leaving Constantinople for Sinope to take 10,000 sleepers for the Hedjaz Railway which are lying there ready for shipment. Salih Youssoufoglou Izren a wealthy Mahomedan merchant established at Moscow, has contributed £t.400 to the Railway fund in his name and in the name of his two sons. The financial commission of the Railway has further received £t. 200 from two Mahomedans of Cossova in the Crimea.

div.head: Lord Cromer and Tropical Medicine
div.p: Lord Cromer and Tropioal Medicine. Lord Cromer has notified his willingness to become an honorary vice president of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine Lord Cromer’s long experience in a sub tropical country has given him ample opportunities of observing the progress that has been made of late years in tropical medicine. He has taken a special interest iv the anti-malarial operations which have been carried on with such success at Ismailia. Under the superintendence of Professor Ronald Ross, Ismailia, which used to be a hotbed of malaria, is now absolutely free of the scourge.

div.head: "The Geisha" at the Alhambra.
div.p: An appreciative and crowded assembly witnessed a performance of that excellent musical comedy, “The Geisha,” at the Alhambra last night The celebrated Roman company, the Lirica Lillipuziana, were the entertainers, and were it not for the use of the Italian language Englishmen present could have fancied themselves at the London theatre where the play was first produced. The acting reached a high standard, and the singing was also extremely good. Special mention should be made of A. DiCastro, Silvio Darienzo, and Alfredo De Mareo amongst the gentlemen the latter being particularly humorous as Wum-Hi—and Maria Cecearelli, Dora Theor, and Elvira Motti, amongst the ladies. ‘The artistes well merited the hearty applause which greeted them at frequent intervals during the progress of the play. The scenery, which was very realistic, also deserves favourable mention

div.head: World's Heavy Weight Championship
div.p: (Gazzette's Special Service)
London, Tuesday.
At the contest for the worlds heavyweight boxing championships at the National Sporting Club, Burns of America beat Moir of England in the tenth round. It was a very poor fight.

div.head: Death of Father Schmidt
div.p: (Gazzette's Special Service)
London, Tuesday
Father Schmidt, th ehead of the Roman Catholic Hospice at Jerusalem, has died at Cologne as a result of an accident

div.head: The Khedive
div.p: Yesterday morning the Khedive received the Duke of Brunswick, Sir Eldon Gorst, Baron de Viegilben, Mr. P W. Machell, and Hassan Bey Hassib, who presented Hassan Pasha Wassif and Mustapha Bey Maher. In the afternoon his Highness returned the visit of the Duke of Brunswick at Shepheard’s Hotel. The Khedive afterwards drove out to Koubbeh Palace, where he spent the night

div.head: Lord Cromer Fund
div.p: At an informal meeting ot British residents of Alexandria, called by Mr. Robert J. Moss, and held at the Union Club yesterday afternoon, it was proposed by Judge Sandars and seconded by Mr. P. W. Carver, that the farewell testimonial to Lord Cromer should take the shape of a yearly prize or scholarship, to be competed for by the pupils of Victoria Collége, irrespective ot pationality. This proposal was carried unanimously. It was further proposed, firstly to appoint a committee, composed of the following :—H. P. Kingham, Robert J. Moss (Chairman) V. FP. Naggiar, Judge Sandars, and W. 'T. Smith. Secondly that Messrs. Russell Kerr and Wyatt be asked to undertake the keeping of accounts, and, thirdly, that the Anglo-Egyptian Bank be asked to receive subscriptions.

div.head: Gold Returns
div.p: The imports of gold to Egypt from November 24 to 30 totalled L.E. 47,964 and the exports L.E. 9,674, making the figures for the whole mouth of November L.E. 919/470 and LE. 26,239 respectively

div.head: The Egyptian Army
div.p: Nothing influences a man of any race, says a correspondent of the “Daily Telegraph,” more than a sense of personal loyalty and responsibility to his Sovereign. It seems, therefore, a matter to be regretted that the young native officer is not presented to his Highness the Kbedive until he has reached the rank of Bimbashi. What reason could be urged against his being presented on joining the Army, as in England, it is diffenlt to understand, for the effect could be nothing but good. I do not, of course, mean to convey the impression that the young officer is perfect, either in disinterestedness or in devotion to duty, but his training is daily giving him a more genuine and more deep rooted patriotic sense.

div.head: Strom at Atbara
div.p: Our Suakim correspondant, writing on the 21st ult. says "Today a fierce wind, which raised veritable clouds of dust, prevailed at Atbara, and caused great inconvenience to all who had to go out of doors. Indeed, people had to cover their faces to prevent the dust of the smothering them, and as a result of this a government clerk, blinded by his protective shield, was run over and killed by a shunting-engine at the railway crossing. The Body discovered severed into four parts He leaves a widow and five children.

div.head: Polo Match
div.p: No.3 ground at Ghezireh after its long rest is playing excellently now, and we witnessed a good match this afternoon between the King’s Own Scottish Borderers team and the Coldstream Guards

This was a good game, the hitting and com-bination being good on both sides. The Coldstream Guards won rather unexpectedly by 5 goals to 3. Capt. Stoney was not quite in his usual good form at back - and Mr. Bentinck for the Guards was left “loose” nearly the whole game and consequently did most of the scoring. Capt. Sterling played a strong gaim at back for the Guards, and hit one very good goal from a penalty shot.

div.head: Cassa Di Sconto E Di Risparmio
div.p: A une demande de renseignements que nous avions adressée 4 Azny Bey au sujet de I’as- signation lancée par lui contre la Cassa di Sconto, il nous a répondu par la lettre suivante :

Monsieur le Directeur de’ “Egyptian Gazette,” J'ai l'hogneur de vous accuser réception de votre honorée en date d’hier, et vous remercie de votre offre courtoise. Cependant, j'ai le regret de décliner cette offre, car j'estime qu'il est préférable de Inisser la Justice se prononcer sur le proces que j'in- tente A la Cassa, sans faire précéder le juge- ment que je sollicite par des considérationas. de presse, basées sur l'opinion de l'une ou |'autre des parties en cause, Toutefois, et si mon désir du silence se trouve un jour changé par l'attitude des or- ganes de nos adversaires, je vous prie deme réserver-votre sollicitude et l’appui de votre estimable journal, car ma cause est celle sur- tout de ceux qui ne peuvent ou qui n'osert se défendre contre les grands financiers. Veuillez agréer, Monsieur le Directeur, l’assurance de ma haute considération. Azmy. A peine avions-nous fecu cette lettre qu’Azmy Bey se présentait lui-cméme 4 noe bureaux, plein d'indignation a la suite des faits que nous allons mgenter : Plosieurs banquesa de la ville sont en train d’exercer une pression sur leurs cliemts auxquels ils menacent decouper tout crédit et de réclamer lears comptes courants, s'ils se rallient a l'ac- tion intentée par Azmy Bey & la Cassa di Sconto. L’une d'elles, en autres, a obligé un ingénieur bien connu de notre ville 4 retirer sa signature de la liste des actionnaires adhé- rents A la cause d’Azmy Bey. Cet ingénieur a du bon gré mal gré s'exécuter pour ne pas s’ex poser A perdre un crédit que ses entreprises rendent absolument indispensable. D’autres personnes ayant apposé leur signatore a la liste ont aussi été l'objet de menaces 8 et sont venues chez Azmy Bey lui réclamer le retrait de leur signature. Devant l'exposé de telles mesures et sur le désir exprimé par Azmy Bey, nous ne poa- vons que nous abstenir detous commentaires et laisser le public juge de l’affaire. Azmy Bey croit savoir qu'il n'y anra pas de convocation de l'assembiée générale, puisque les liquidateurs ont nommé de nombreux avo- cats parmi les plus en vue. Que le conseil attaqué par lui se défende, fort bien, dit Azmy Bey, mais 'intervention des liquidateurs lui parait déplacée. Que demande-t:il, en effet la vérification des comptes et la communication aux actionnaires de la situation. Pour couper court & toute l'affaire, les liquidateurs n'ont dove qu’é fournir les éclaircissements de- mandés

div.head: Cholera at Constantinople
div.p: The Sultan's Fears

The following is the full report of the Constanntinople corresepondant of the "Daily Telegraph" on which our special service telegram of the 27 inst. was based:- Great alarm has been caused in high quarters by the discovery last week and Stanbaul of a fatal case of Cholera followed by another which was not fatal. the batch of pilgrims, come on to Constantinople after having gone through 5 days quarantine at Sinope. The whole batch has now been sent to a lazaretto, in orders came from the palace for severe measures to be taken for the future. to a prophecy of a gypsy before he ascended the throne, the sultan has always been terribly afraid of cholera and plague , and at the slightest signs of either of these diseases he sends irades to the Board of Health ordering all sorts of measures to be taken, in the Board of Health has a very bad time trying to make reasonable Arrangements. in order to prevent any further Danger from pilgrims, of whom enormous numbers from Russia, Caucasus, Afghanistan, Persia, and Bokhars are passing through the Bosepherus on their way to Mecca, it has been ordered that all our kin undergo 5 days quarantine at Sinope, in the Black Sea, after which steamers are to embark them at Sinope and take them direct to Djedda, not stopping at Constantinople at all. This is most inconvenient to the pilgrims in the business World in Constantinople: some 20,000 or 30,000 pilgrims pass this way, and as they look upon Constantinople as a place to make their final Arrangements, they bring with them carpets, rugs etc., for sale, and buy all the necessaries for the voyage, and also to a large amount of sightseeing and the capital of the Caliph. They are the natural prey of a large number of counts, who robbed and swindled them as much as possible, so that all together they represent the loss of a large amount of money to the account A few years ago a most Swindle was perpetrated on a party of pilgrims. The Fledjog Railway was then first heard of, and A Tout told the pilgrims that he would send them by rail to Mecca at the cost of 1 a head, instead of 8, as the Steamers were taking to Djeddah. the pilgrims were delighted and he collected one from each and took them to the funicular railway from Galata to Pera, the cost of one penny place them and told them they would get a mecha. The train runs about 3 minutes up the hills para underground and returns immediately. After the pilgrims had made several trips to officials noticed them and their explanations began in the pilgrims were turned out to try and catch the tout

div.head: New German Hospital
div.p: (Continued from Yesterday)

Since its foundation half a century ago the founders and many of the sisters have long since left, as well as many doctors who have efficaciously contributed to the progress of the hospital ; I would especially mention the chief doctor, Dr. Varenborat Pasha, no more of this world. The present hospital, whose building is old and delapitated, no longer meeting the wants of a modern house for the sick, has obliged us to commence the construction of a new hospital. But the spirit which has reigned for fifty years in our hospital, the spirit of trust in God, self-denial, sense of duty, and fidelity even unto death, still reigns among the sisters and will enter the new hospital and will grow and flourish. In proceeding under such auspices to lay the foundation stone of this hospital we need not be anxious for the future. We thank the Sovereign of this coun try for the interest which he takes in our hospital. . . . Concordia parvae crescunt. Discordia ma- ximae dilabuntur. Concord. makes the small prosper, discord ruins the great, There has existed in latter years in politics much misunderstanding between Great Britain and Germany, happily now dissipated. Let the example of our hospital, where Great Britain and Germany work hand in hand for charity with great success, serve to re strengthen the bonds between the two peoples so that they may know each other better and better. .

Mr. Wanderlich’s speech was followed by a hymn, after which Mr. Ehrlich described the technical details of the construction. The documents were then handed to Mrs. Wunderlich, who placed them in the stone with the local newspapers of the day and Egyptian coins. The stone was laid by Mr. Wanderlich, who gave it three blows with the hammer, and blows were afterwards given by Count Bernstorff, Youssef Pasha Zia, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Chataway Bey, Mr. E.B. Gould, the president and members of the committe, the leading members of the German colony, Mr. Binderpagel and Mr. von Tschudi of the Swiss Colony, Ven. Archdeacon Ward, and the Evangelical priest of the German Church, who gavea prayer. The ceremony. was concluded with. ahymn and at five o'clock, after partaking of; liberal refreshments, the assembly dispersed. In the evening én unofficial banquet was held at the New ivial Hotel, at which 130 persons were present, and Mr. Wunderlich tack theschair An excellent dinner was served and many congradulations were showered upon Mr. Reinsperger.

div.head: Sudan Budget
div.p: The Sudan Budget for 1908 which we publish below contains no marked diversions from the lines of thosé of previous years, and once more the Egyptian Government will aye every reason to be satisfied with the of events in the Sndan territories. The payment of of LB 45,000 is a first step towards the financial independence of the country, this payment being of course equivalent to a reduction of the sum hitherto allotted to the Sudan by the Egyptian Government. As the budget of 1907 a substantial surplus is expécted, provided that reesipta continue to come in up to a normal standard, and certain economies which have been made in the new Budget should further add to the amount to the Reserve Fand in order to meet sme of the most urgent demands for capital expenditure throughout the Country. It must, however, be borne in mind that this year has been an unfortunate one as far as the Sudan interest are involved, both the exceptionally low Nile and ‘the repeated attacks of the locusts combining to reduce the receipts which will acorne to the budget of 1908, therefore when all this is considered, the increase of L.E. 175,000 estimated for in the budget of 1907 and provided for in the new budget may very possibly be rather in excess of the actual receipts to be obtained. Agricultural receipts too, may now be said to have reached their maximum limits as the Sudan is not allowed to draw upon the water supply of the Nie except during flood. Of course in the above no consideration is taken of the imports to the Sadan on which Customs are levied at Egyptian Ports, and retained by the Egyptian Government The following are the receipts. The. figures are in LE, the first figures, representing the 1908 budget and the second the 1907 budget:—

The total for the provinces in 1908 is LB. 274,250, as against L.B: 258,022 in 1907; Civil Seoretary’s Department, 2,400; 1740. Legal Department, 16,800; 8,600. Post and Telegraphs, 60,000 ; 44,369. Railways, 320,000 ; 262,000.
The total for the above. is L.R 666,300, as against L.B. 523,086 in 1907. Local Provincial Services, 59,661 ; 48,886.

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: Aujour'd hui a midi

Notre marché a présenté ce matin le méme qwhier, c’est-a-dire qu'il ya eu de la les vendeurs s’étant retirés en grande partie dans I’attente de meilleurs prix, les haassiers en ont profité pour pousser les cours et il y ont partaitement réussi. L’attention s'est princi it concentrée sur la National Bank, l’Agricole, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien, la Land Bank, le Comptoir, la Levico, I'Helovan et’ ’Ordinary Khedivial Mail. Il s'agit en général de demande sans C'est précisément l'inverse de naguére, lorsque les offres affluaient sans trouver d’acheteurs. D'un coté commie de l'autre les affaires sont clair- semées ot plus la contre-partie est difficile a trouver plus les oscillations de la cote denvergure. Pour tout dire, Yamélloration constatée sur la Bourse de Paris en valeurs égyptionnes a été pour beaucoup dans la fer- meté de notre marché.

L’ Agricole est recherchée a 7 7/8. La Natio- nal Bank progresse de 20 1/2 & 20 5/8,la Daira de 12 5/8 A 1211/16, et Obligation Crédit Foncier de 285 1/2 & 286 1/2 l’ancienhe et de 252 4253 la nouvelle.

La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux d’Asphaltage d'un pattie de la Ree Porte Rosette. Le cautionnement est fixé & LEg. 1,300. Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Techvique ot i peut étre consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9h. a midi, les jours fériés exceptés.

Les offres devront tre adressées sons pli cecheté a Monsieur ’Administrateor de la Manicipalité avant le 24 Décembre 1907. Elles pourront également étre déposées en séance de la Délégation le méme jour a 5h. pm. ‘enveloppe devra porter en outre la mentien: “Soumission poor ‘Asphaltage Rue Porte Rosette.”

div.head: The American Crisis
div.p: Big Exodus
The President's Message

New York, December 2. 12,000 people compoxed of laborers and their families sailed for Europe on Seturday, which makes the total for the week 69,000. The reason is on account of unemployment. (Reuter)

New York, December 2. The forecast of President Roosevelt's message has contributed toa revival in Wall Street owing to the moderation of its tone. He favours the issue of emergency currency secured by bonds, which would be taxed sufficiently to enforce their redemption when the emergency was past. He advises the federal supervision of corporations, which would restore confidence in their stocks and remedy abuses. He does not object to railways combining under the restrictions safe-guarded by the interstate commission which should be empowered to control the fresh issue of stock. He favours tariff revision after the presidential election, and urges the construction of four very large battleships armed with the largest guns. 1,500,000 dollars worth of gold was engaged to-day for import to America. (Reuter)

div.head: Troubles in S. Africa
div.p: Chase of Dinizulu
Pietermaritzburg, December 2. A force will start to-morrow to arrest Dinizolu, who has 500 followers partly armed. (Reuter)

Pietermaritzburg, December 2. Nearly 2,000 troops will operate in Zulu land. The main force will leave to-day for Gingiudhlova. Colonel Mackenzie and Staff will leave to-morrow. A general rising is not expected but all contingencies are being prepared for. ( Reuter )

div.head: The Moors and Algeria
div.p: Further Fighting

Algiers, December 2. The French force on the frontier had further fighting on Saturday. 80 of the enemy were killed and many wounded. The French had no casualties. General Lyautey is preparing three columns at points in the vicinity of the frontier. (Reuter)
Paris, December 2. General Drude denies that the Bagdadi Meballa guns have been taken. (Havas)

div.head: The German Scandals
div.p: Prince Bulow's Repudiation

Berlin, December 2. All the newspapers express satisfaction at the energetic repndiation by Prince von Bulow of the senseless generalizations in the Moltke Harden case and also at the detailed exactitude with which the War Minister proved that they were the outcome of the secret errors of some people who remained unknown to their chiefs and friends. (Reuter)

div.head: Chamber of Deputies
div.p: Paris, December 2. The Chamber of Deputies has adopted an amendment fixing the reservists periods at 21 to 15 days. (Havas)

div.head: The Congo Treaty
div.p: Brussels, December 2. Belgian and Congolese plniptentiaries signed on 29th November a treaty wherby Belguim takes over the Congo. (Reuter)

div.head: The Goold Trial
div.p: The Goold Trial. Monaco, December 2. The Goold trial has begun. (Havas)

div.head: A Mimic Bombardment
div.p: London, December 2.The “Dominion,” “Hibernia,” “Triumph,” and “Vengeance” bombarded an old battleship equipped under war conditions, with a dummy crew, on the Kentish coast. The range was from 6,000 to 8,000 yards and the weather was perfect. It is reported that 28 out of 180 rounds were effective. (Reuter)

div.head: The Duma
div.p: St. Petersburg, December 2. The Tsar has approved the address of the Duma, from which he declares that he expects productive work. (Havas)

div.head: The Austrian Ministry
div.p: Vienna December 3.The departmental head, Herr von Georgi, has sueceeded Herr Lauendorf, Minister of Defence, who has retired. ( Reuter)

div.head: The Persian Parliament
div.p: Teheran, December 2. The Shab in a reseript to Parliament protests against Parliament's interference with his executive powers. The members denied the interference and blamed the Shah for his laxity as head of the Executive Council. ( Reuter)

div.head: M.C.C. Beat Queensland
div.p: Brisbane, December 2. Cricket. M.C.C beat Queensland by an innings and 44 runs.(Reuter)

div.head: Terrible Colliery Explosion
div.p: Washington, December 2. Sixty miners have been entombed owing to acolliery explosion at Monongahela. It is believed that all have been asphyxiated. (Renter)

div.head: Obituary
div.p: Monaco, December 2. Count Montebello, ex-ambassafor is dead. (Havas)
Paris, December 3. Count de Montebello ex-Ambassador of France at St. Petersburg. (Reuter)

div.head: Letter to The Editor
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by out correspondants, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
Cairo's Housing Problem

To The Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette" Sir,—I had hoped before intruding on space to have had the advantage of reading some further correspondence on the subject of the housing problem referred to by “Interested” in your issue of the 16th inst. but as none has so far appeared, I forward my small contribution on this interesting subject.

I do not think that the proposition made by “Interested” viz : that the government should build dwelling houses in Cairo in which to house the government employés is one which would commend itself, There are many objections to the Government making itself the landlord of employés owing allegiance to a dozen different countries, and one shudders to think what would be the outcome of disputes between landlord and tenant ; the possible and more than probable complications would be infinite, Further, in the opinion of many, Cairo is already overbuilt and overcrowded, and open spaces rather than huge blocks of build- ings are the first desideratum, but I am not qualified to express a personal opinion on this point. Further I am given to understand that the Government does not now possess in the city itself any suitable sites for residential purposes—and to buy at the present high prices any suitable sites so far as position and healthy surroundings are concerned is quite out of the question—for the purchase money for the land itself would preclude, owing to the interest charge, the building of “sky- scrapers” even, which could be let off as apart- ments at rentals within the means of the lower paid employés. It must not be forgotten that large airy apartments’are wanted, for I take it for granted that the married employés would have first consideration ; contracted, stuffy rooms are not the best adapted for the healthy upbringing of children- and such places do not conduce to the health of the head of the family either.

A solution for the housing problem must be looked for owtside the city itself—in the respective suburbs,-and now that communication by rail and tram is so extended and improved, the problem is greatly simplified. (To avoid any misconception, let me say at once that the only piece of land I possess is situated at Old Cairo, so that “Interested” and others may rest assured that I am not by some side issue trying to work off another speculative land boom ; I do not even like to speculate over that diminative plot I possess.)

Years since, before a land boom was even thought of, bundreds, nay thousands of building plots were disposed of by the government and private individuals at prices ranging from a few paras to a few piastres the metre, and with the exception of one district, but a small proportion of these sites have been utilised owing to the then absence of rapid and frequent communication—a matter which I have already pointed out has of recent years been remedied.

It would not be possible without a canvass to ascertain how many of these unused sites are still held by government employes, but it would be quite safe to say that some hundreds are. What then is required as a financial group, a local one by preference, who would be prepared to advance capital to Government employés (and may be permanent residents) with which to construct cottages or bungalows on building sites already belonging to them. Such struc- tures should be well built, and if not aesthetic should be at least pleasing to the eye extern- ally, and comfortable internaliy. The financial group might constitute itself its own con- tractors for building, or in the event of a technical employé chosing to superintend the work for himself or any of his colleagues, an expert of the group might be appointed to check off quantities — and this more as a matter of form. In the event of an ‘outside’ contractor being employed, the expert of the group would of course have a heavier task to perform, but then the financial group and the one for whom the hense was being built would be matually interested in ensuring against scainped work or the employment of inferior material and fittings.

An interest charge would be made on the sum advanced (representing actaal rental) and to this shonld be added an amortization charge, so that in a few years time the employe becomes his own land-lord. It is not necessary now to enter into details as to the interest to be charged or the amorti- zation to be arranged for, the first would not of course exceed the legal rate and most likely would be much below, while the second is one to be arranged for by mutual agree ment ; nor need I now refer to the question of “surrender” in the event of the householder being transferred to another town or district, or leaving the country, suffice to say that the subject has been well considered.

It will have been at once seen how advan- as the arrangement I have suggested would be to the land-owning employé and any financial group, syndicate, or company formed to advance the required capital; the former would not have included in his rental an interest charge on the purchase price of the land apon which his house is built — as it already belongs to him, while the latter would not be called upon to sink capital in building sites which might or might not be taken up, they would only have to provide, as required, the capital requisite for buildings which would bring in immediate returns, and they would be more than guaranteed against any risk of loss by the temporary cession to them of th¢ title deeds to the land pending the amortization of the debt.

The foregoing is but a very bare outline of a scheme which I have discussed with « large number of government officials, and I should be glad to see in the “Gazette” the opinions and criticisms of “Interested” and others on the principle of the scheme. Yours, ete. A. Crossan. Calro, November 29.

div.head: Un Parti Republican En Egypt
div.p: J'ai ln dans votre excellent journal la nou- velle qui yous est parvenue de source sfre, selon l’expression de votre correspondant, qu'un parti républicain étaiten voie de forma- tion au Caire et prendrait place parmi les Pattis politiques existants. Je tiens & exprimer 4 “l’Egyptian Gazette” mon admiration pour avoir publié une si im- portante nouvelle avant tout autre journal et aussi pour la oélérité de son service d’informa- tions; mais mon étonnement est grand lorsque le correspondant de la ‘(lazette” dit tenir la nouvelle de source autorisée. Point de doute sur la formation do Parti Républicain, car des patriotes avisés se sont assembiés pour discuter la situation actoelle et ont résolu, non seulement de fonder le Parti, mais d’élaborer son programme et de soumettre prochainement Programme et Parti 4 l'opinion publique. Il serait surperfia que je décrive ici |'utilité de ce Parti, car il aura un journal qui sera chargé de propager et de défendre I’Idéal de la République Egyptienne. Le Parti tiendra sa premiére séance dans les premiers jours de décembre prochain et dans le local d’un des principaux cercles di Caire ; alors |’opiniun publique Egyptienne se rendra un compte exact des principes, du but et de la volonté du Parti Républicain Egyptien. Pour le moment j’affirmerai avec une entire franchise que la fondation du Parti Républicain en ce moment aura un retentissement assez considérable, car sa création est d’utilitégénérale. Au cas od il me paraitrait urgent de tenir l'opinion au courant par la voie de votre esti- mable journal, j’aurai recours 4 votre graciense hospitalité pour une autre lettre. Avec mes remerciements croyez moi, Mon- sieur le Directeur, votre trés dévouéd.
Mohamed Ganem
Le Caire, le 28 Novembre 1907

div.head: Egypt 100 Years Ago
div.p: The English at Alexandria
(From “The Times,” November 25, 1807) Translation of a Turkish Dispatch presented by his Excellency Mouhammed Ali Pasha, Governor of Egypt, to his Highness the Caimakan Pasha.
[Upon the upper margin, to the left, is written the following note, in red letters, probably by the Reis Effendi : ‘Tis is a dispatch of your slave, Mouhammed Ali Pasha, Governor of Egypt"]
“To his Highness the most High, most Fortanate, mest Generous Lord, my most Respectable and most Honoured Brother.

“The supreme will of his Highness being, that the impure presence of the English infidels, who had at the time taken possession, by sur- prise, of the tortress of Alexandria, should cease to sully this territory, and that the said fortress should be with the help of the Most High, retaken, and submitted to its lawful possessor, in order to conform to the noble command, the frontispiece of which was decorated with the sacred character of the Imperial hand, and ad- dressed to the Undersigned, his most humble slave, I hastened to assemble every thing that was necessary to the success of this military ex- pedition ; and from the first day of the moon of Djema-zied-Oughra (about the sth August), I set off from Cairo at the head of all the cavalry, and the flower of the infantry, and marched straight against the enemy.

“I pitched my camp in the plain of Damen- khor, six leagues from the place called Sed, an intrenched post of the English. I sent during the night afew of the light horse to the spot, for the purpose of reconnoitering the position of the English, and the means to be taken for surrounding them. I marched forward myself, and secured the most proper place for the raising of my batteries, and for the introduction of the armed boats and gun-barks into the two lakes, which are upon both flanks of the Sed. This operation, performed in the silence of the night, baving lasted for some time, could not be concealed from the knowledge of the boats which the enemy kept stationed upon the lakes. Accordingly, he fired many cannon shots, which happily did as no damage. However, this first movement on our part had already given him the alarm, and the next day we saw arrive, with the Major who bad been sent to me twice before as a negociator, the second in command of the English forces, accompanied by two other persons, and who took the title of Plenipotentiary, appointed both by thé Com- mander of the squadron, and by the General of the land forces to conelnde peace. The Plenipo- ee ee in support of his character his tials, The sense of these the language of the bearer, and the result of the conference, amounted upon the whole to these few words:-

“These propositions, which the English without there being yet any attack on ei side, having been in Council, accepted. It was considered that thoughh the Infidels employ cunning and craft, the Sword of the true Faith always predominates, on the other hand it was that the Sed could not be carried, without troops there ; and that, on account of which the Nile leaves uncovered in the ordinary course, the landing depends on the great increase of the waters of that river, which, having inudated the hwole surface of th earth, would everywhere favour the entrance of the boats and the gunbarks. Now the overflow of the Nile has been middl- ing this year, and does not allow these barks to venture into this shallow water. It would, no doubt, be possible to take vengeance, by another means, of our enemies; but if we gave them time, they might receive succours and rein- forcements. From these considerations, we confined ourselves to requiring some conditions, and the accommodation was signed.

"I directly dispatched to Alexandria, in order to take immediate possession of the town and fortifications, of the artillery, warlike stores, and other things most esssential; and I myself, to-day, Tuesday, 19th of the Moon Redjele (22 Sept.) made my entry into this town which have been at length purged of the infidels who sullied it and is now returned ander the Musselman dominion, glory be to the Most High. So gteat a favour from ‘the God of Mercy, and the signal grace which he vouchsafed to the most feeble of his slaves, in taking him for the instrument of the recaptare of Alexandria, and of the execution of the Imperial will, must be exclusively attributed to the infinite merit of bis Highness, my most formidable, most powerful, and very miracul- ous Emperor and Master, and imputed to his fortunate star.”

div.head: Constipation
div.p: To ensure a natural movement of the bowels, it is most important to take plenty of exercise every day. Many men and women don’t do this, and they become more or less costive, sometimes going two or three days without a passage from the bowels. This is a very serious thing, not only because constipation makes our food and blood impure, but because the prolonged presence of waste matter in the bowels strains the muscular walls, eventually paralysing them, so that instruments have to be used to remove the impurities.

Those who cannot get enouglr exercise, or whose work is sedentary, sbould use Doan’s Dinner Pills, which are made from pure roots and herbs that act on the bowels, invigorating the muscular Walls, and toning up the nerves, liver, stomach, and whole digestive organism. Doan’s Dinner Pills soften the mass of clogging waste, preventing piles, and inflammation of intestines ; and they cure sluggish liver, indi- gestion, bilousness, headache, poor appetite, impoverished blood, and every symptom of liver, stomach, or bowel trouble.

Doan’s Dinner Pills are sold by all chemists and druggists, at 5 P.T. per box, or 80 P.T. for six boxes ; or they may be bought direct from the agents from Egypt, Mr. E.
